text:
Remember that my father was a refugee
from Palestine who came to Jordan in 1948,

and he started as an employee
for four years. Then he started

his trading business in FMCGs,
fast moving consumer goods.

1958 was his first activity
in industrial production.

However, I was born in
1962 and he was a

self-made man,
single-handedly doing everything.

And when I was a young boy,
his history and the struggle

as a refugee was part of our
upbringing, believe it or not.

It was something that was talked about
almost every day, not always in sad sense.

In fact, more so in a good sense
- that we have to succeed.
We have no choice as a big family.

And I remember that I used to work with him
ever since I was a kid in his shop
in downtown Amman.
Every time he would tell me,

"this is where I will put your desk
when you graduate from college."
So he started planting in my mind

that my role as his eldest
son was to continue his journey.

In 1985, my father,
as I mentioned -

being a self-made man - it
was a one-man show.

He had five companies at the time,
and he had a group of loyal employees,

if you will, but not graduates
and people who went to colleges.

A few of them had
college degrees, but

very few. The majority
didn't have any college degree.

So he was doing, believe
it or not, every single thing -

writing telexes at the time before the
fax even came into existence,

buying machines, buying parts,
inviting the export managers of all

the international companies
we used to import materials

or machines from to our home
to have lunch with our family.
It was his life.
It was his life.

The values of the company, in my mind,
are comprised of many things.

One, whether you're Christian, Muslim,
Jewish, Buddhist, what have you -

we are all similar when we
say God's requests from us.

Don't cheat, don't steal,
don't backstab people.
Do well - do good to people.

Be kind, be generous,
all of that. This is one side.
The second part of the values

is that we invest in talent
and we don't discriminate.
Thirdly, we serve our communities.

Fourth is that we
compete honorably.
We will never compete dishonorably.

I can tell you that we can never cheat on
income tax to, you know, lower costs.
We can never cheat on customs, etc.
